an8.23:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine.
an8.23:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an8.23:4.3: “Mendicants, you should remember the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī as someone who has seven amazing and incredible qualities.
an8.23:4.12: You should remember the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī as someone who has these seven amazing and incredible qualities.”
an8.23:4.13: This is what the Buddha said.
an8.23:4.14: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
an8.23:5.1: Then a certain mendicant got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the home of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī,
an8.23:5.2: where he sat on the indicated seat.
an8.23:5.3: Then Hatthaka went up to that mendicant,
an8.23:5.4: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an8.23:6.1: “Householder, the Buddha declared that you have seven amazing and incredible qualities.
an8.23:6.10: The Buddha declared that you have these seven amazing and incredible qualities.”
an8.23:6.11: “But sir, I trust that no white-clothed lay people were present?”
an8.23:6.12: “No, there weren’t any white-clothed lay people present.”
an8.23:7.1: Then that mendicant, after taking alms-food in Hatthaka of Āḷavī’s home, got up from his seat and left.
an8.23:7.2: Then after the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha,
an8.23:7.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
an8.23:7.4: and told him of what he had discussed with the householder Hatthaka. The Buddha said:
an8.23:10.2: That son of a good family has few wishes.
an8.23:10.3: He doesn’t want his own good qualities to be made known to others.
an8.23:10.4: Well then, mendicant, you should remember the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī as someone who has this eighth amazing and incredible quality, that is, fewness of wishes.”
